author: Jason Beattie
title: Watch the awkward moment top Tory finally admits the truth about tax credit cuts
text:
A Tory minister has finally admitted that people will be worse off as a result of George Osborne’s tax credit cuts .
So far senior Conservatives have refused to accept that millions will lose out by claiming the shortfall will be met by the increase in wages.
David Cameron was the latest to spin the line when grilled by Jeremy Corbyn at Prime Minister’s questions this afternoon.
But Treasury minister David Gauke was forced to admit the cuts to tax credits will not be covered by the increase to the minimum wage.
After repeated questioning on the BBC’s Daily Politics, he said: “There are some people who will be worse off.”
David Gauke clearly knows about cuts...
His comments came as Mr Corbyn challenged David Cameron over the case of Kelly, a single mother with a disabled child, who is set to lose £1,800 in working tax credits.
The Labour leader said the Tory government was “taking away the opportunities and limiting the life chances of hundreds of thousands of children.”
“The reality is people in work often do rely on tax credits to make ends meet. Your party and yourself have put forward a budget which cuts tax credits, gives tax breaks to the very wealthiest in our society, so inequality is getting worse not better.
“Should you not think for a moment about the choices you are making and the reality it is for the very poorest people in our society?” he told the PM.
Video loading Watch next Watch this video again Watch Next
Mr Cameron replied by saying that Kelly would benefit from the rise in the minimum wage.
“What we are doing is bringing in the national living wage, which will be a £20-a-week pay rise for people next year. Obviously Kelly will benefit as that national living wage rises to £9,” he said.
But the PM failed to mention that the tax credit cuts will be cut from April 2016 but the £9-an-hour rate will not start until 2020.
PA Cut to the quick: Labour's Seema Malhotra says there is no defence for the tax credit cuts
Labour’s Treasury spokeswoman Seema Malhotra MP said: “David Gauke has been forced to admit that families who are working hard and depend on tax credits to make ends meet will be worse off after the Tories tax credit cuts come into effect in April 2016.
“Until now Government Ministers - including the Prime Minister - have tried to pretend that the increase in the national minimum wage will more than compensate for the tax credit cuts.
"David Gauke has blown the lid off that defence. I shall be writing to the Prime Minister demanding that he clarify the impact on the income of hard working families of his tax credits cuts .”
